video.title: The 2025 Summer Game Drought Vote | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
This is a recorded message. Yahtzee isn&#39;t in 
right now. It&#39;s his summer holiday, so he took

his kids to the beach. Like a normal person. Who 
doesn&#39;t hang around YouTube, mashing refresh,

expecting game reviews despite knowing full 
well that big game releases are to summer

what a high starch diet was to the Irish Potato 
Famine. But there is something to talk about.

We&#39;ve made a habit each year of getting the 
Patreon subscribers to vote for what classic

or overlooked game I have to do a Fully 
Ramblomatic review of during one week of

the summer game drought. Editor Nick waded 
into the Discord to solicit suggestions and,

by some horrifying arcane process known only to 
him, settled upon the following six finalists.

1. Danganronpa.
Making its third

appearance in the finals, the anime detective 
game is a popular recommendation but has a

habit of being outvoted at the last stretch. 
It was pipped at the post by Chrono Trigger

in 2023 and Knights of the Old Republic in 
2024. Let&#39;s see if this year the weeb bloc

can finally come together to outvote the retro 
weebs and the boring-arse normal-brained people.

2. Sid Meier&#39;s Pirates!
(I think that&#39;s how you pronounce that.)

The 2004 remake rather than the 1987 original. 
I mean, Jesus Christ, we&#39;re up for retro gaming,

but we&#39;re not about to go back to running games 
on fucking oscilloscopes or stone tablets. I think

someone might have heard a rumor that I like 
anything with an 18th century nautical theme,

so perhaps we&#39;ll see how that rubs up 
against my attitude towards minigames.

3. Deep Rock Galactic.
A multiplayer mining survival-type game about

space dwarfs. Which I have played. Didn&#39;t really 
gel with it much, but I can see how it might

appeal. Not entirely clear on why someone thinks 
it&#39;d be funny to make me play it again. Maybe

because I am basically the diametric opposite of 
a space dwarf, that is, an earthbound tall person.

4. Jade Empire.
I had to look this

one up. Apparently, it was an action RPG made 
by BioWare in 2005 as an Xbox exclusive (and

which nobody bought). Good reviews, but 
no sequels were forthcoming. Apparently,

it was the decision to focus on this and Dragon 
Age that meant BioWare didn&#39;t make Knights of

the Old Republic 2, so maybe one of those KOTOR 
fans from last year is still harboring a grudge.

5. Factorio.
The original top-down 2D game

about factory-making and pretty much bugger all 
else, this one got pretty damn close to winning

last year. Christ knows why. I think it has one 
of those rabid fanbases who insist that &quot;No,

really, you too will soon become obsessed 
with creating visual metaphors for my

internal thought processes when I&#39;m trying to 
find room in my schedule for a sneaky wank.&quot;

6. Elden Ring: Nightreign.
I was turned off Nightreign

by its multiplayer focus, but frankly, there&#39;s 
no rational reason for why I haven&#39;t played it

yet except that I just... don&#39;t really wanna. 
The old Soulslike fatigue again. Still haven&#39;t

finished base Elden Ring or played the 
DLC. I&#39;ll play Nightreign if you insist;

I just find less appeal these days 
in getting pounded into the dirt by

a 12-hit combo from a huge, flaily lad with 
a very prominent adjective in their name.

And that&#39;s this year&#39;s six finalists, so 
now all that remains is for you guys to

vote on which one will get the 
Fully Ramblomatic treatment at

some as-yet-undetermined point in this 
year&#39;s summer game drought. Remember,

only Patreon subscribers at the $5 a month tier or 
above get to vote, so if you want to have a voice,

go to patreon.com/secondwindgroup and sign up. 
You&#39;ll get all sorts of other perks and bonus

videos as well. If you don&#39;t want to do that or 
can&#39;t afford it, feel free to have an informal

straw poll in the comments of this video. 
Maybe a Patreon subscriber will pass by and

be swayed by your arguments. I mean, we managed 
to persuade them to give us money every month;

they&#39;re presumably a fairly malleable bunch. 
That concludes this recording. If you&#39;d like

to leave a message, please stick it 
up your bum when you hear the tone.
